001package com.technototes.library.command;
002
003import androidx.annotation.Nullable;
004import com.technototes.library.general.Periodic;
005import com.technototes.library.structure.CommandOpMode;
006import com.technototes.library.subsystem.Subsystem;
007import java.util.HashMap;
008import java.util.LinkedHashSet;
009import java.util.Map;
010import java.util.Set;
011import java.util.function.BooleanSupplier;
012
013/**
014 * This is a "singleton" object for scheduling commands. Most usage originates from {@link Command}
015 * methods {@link Command#andThen} or {@link Command#alongWith} for example. Outside of
016 * those usages, you will typically use {@code CommandScheduler.getInstance().scheduleJoystick} to
017 * control a drivebase.
018 *
019 * <p>
020 * TODO: The "CommandScheduler.getInstance()" thing is really kinda silly. Perhaps it's how WPIlib
021 * TODO: works, but it's clunky and makes things messier for non-FRC programmers. I think I'm going
022 * TODO: yoink that method and make static methods for next year's release...
023 */
024public final class CommandScheduler {
025
026    private final Map<Command, BooleanSupplier> commandMap;
027    private final Map<Subsystem, Set<Command>> requirementMap;
028    private final Map<Subsystem, Command> defaultMap;
029
030    private final Set<Periodic> registered;
031
032    private CommandOpMode opMode;
033
034    /**
035     * Set the scheduler's opmode
036     *
037     * @param c the opmode
038     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
039     */
040    public CommandScheduler setOpMode(CommandOpMode c) {
041        opMode = c;
042        return this;
043    }
044
045    /**
046     * Forcefully halt the opmode
047     *
048     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
049     */
050    public CommandScheduler terminateOpMode() {
051        opMode.terminate();
052        return this;
053    }
054
055    /**
056     * Gets the number of seconds that the opmode has been executing
057     *
058     * @return elapsed time since opmode was started, in seconds
059     */
060    public double getOpModeRuntime() {
061        return opMode.getOpModeRuntime();
062    }
063
064    // The Singleton CommandScheduler
065    private static CommandScheduler instance;
066
067    /**
068     * Get (or create) the singleton CommandScheduler object
069     *
070     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton
071     */
072    public static synchronized CommandScheduler getInstance() {
073        if (instance == null) {
074            instance = new CommandScheduler();
075        }
076        return instance;
077    }
078
079    /**
080     * Alex had a comment "be careful with this" and he's not wrong.
081     * This removes the old Singleton and creates a new one. That's pretty dangerous...
082     *
083     * @return a *new* singleton object (which makes very little sense)
084     */
085    public static synchronized CommandScheduler resetScheduler() {
086        instance = null;
087        Command.clear();
088        return getInstance();
089    }
090
091    private CommandScheduler() {
092        commandMap = new HashMap<>();
093        requirementMap = new HashMap<>();
094        defaultMap = new HashMap<>();
095        registered = new LinkedHashSet<>();
096    }
097
098    /**
099     * Schedule a command to run
100     *
101     * @param command the command to schedule
102     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
103     */
104    public CommandScheduler schedule(Command command) {
105        return schedule(command, () -> true);
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Schedule a command to run
110     *
111     * @param command the command to schedule
112     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
113     */
114    public CommandScheduler scheduleOnce(Command command) {
115        return schedule(command);
116    }
117
118    /**
119     * Schedule a command to run during a particular OpModeState
120     *
121     * @param command the command to schedule
122     * @param state   the state during which the command should be scheduled
123     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
124     */
125    public CommandScheduler scheduleOnceForState(Command command, CommandOpMode.OpModeState state) {
126        return scheduleForState(command, state);
127    }
128
129    /**
130     * Schedule a command to be run recurringly during the 'Init' phase of an opmode.
131     * This can be used for vision, as well as running any system to help the
132     * drive team ensure that the robot is appropriately positioned on the field.
133     * This will only be run if the BooleanSupplier 'supplier' is also true!
134     *
135     * @param command  The command to run
136     * @param supplier The condition which also must be true to run the command
137     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
138     */
139    public CommandScheduler scheduleInit(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
140        return scheduleForState(command, supplier, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.INIT);
141    }
142
143    /**
144     * Schedule a command to be run recurringly during the 'Init' phase of an opmode.
145     * This can be used for vision, as well as running any system to help the
146     * drive team ensure that the robot is appropriately positioned on the field.
147     *
148     * @param command The command to run
149     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
150     */
151    public CommandScheduler scheduleInit(Command command) {
152        return scheduleForState(command, () -> true, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.INIT);
153    }
154
155    /**
156     * Schedules a command to be run during Run and End states, all the time.
157     * This is called "Schedule for Joystick" because joysticks don't really have a
158     * condition you might consider 'useful for triggering', so the command
159     * just runs repeatedly. This adds the requirement that the BooleanSupplier function
160     * is also true for the command to be run.
161     *
162     * @param command  The command to run repeatedly
163     * @param supplier The condition which must also be true to run the command
164     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
165     */
166    public CommandScheduler scheduleJoystick(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
167        return scheduleForState(
168            command,
169            supplier,
170            CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN,
171            CommandOpMode.OpModeState.END
172        );
173    }
174
175    /**
176     * Schedules a command to be run during Run and End states, all the time.
177     * This is called "Schedule for Joystick" because joysticks don't really have a
178     * condition you might consider 'useful for triggering', so the command
179     * just runs repeatedly
180     *
181     * @param command The command to run repeatedly.
182     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
183     */
184    public CommandScheduler scheduleJoystick(Command command) {
185        return scheduleForState(
186            command,
187            CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN,
188            CommandOpMode.OpModeState.END
189        );
190    }
191
192    /**
193     * Schedule a command to be run when the OpMode is one of the provided list of states and the
194     * 'supplier' boolean function is also true.
195     *
196     * @param command  The command to run
197     * @param states   The list of states to schedule the command
198     * @param supplier The function to determin in the command should be scheduled
199     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
200     */
201    public CommandScheduler scheduleForState(
202        Command command,
203        BooleanSupplier supplier,
204        CommandOpMode.OpModeState... states
205    ) {
206        return schedule(
207            command.cancelUpon(() -> !opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)),
208            () -> supplier.getAsBoolean() && opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)
209        );
210    }
211
212    /**
213     * Schedule a command to be run when the OpMode is one of the provided list of states.
214     *
215     * @param command The command to run
216     * @param states  The list of states to schedule the command
217     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
218     */
219    public CommandScheduler scheduleForState(Command command, CommandOpMode.OpModeState... states) {
220        return schedule(
221            command.cancelUpon(() -> !opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)),
222            () -> opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)
223        );
224    }
225
226    /**
227     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
228     * finished (but *not* been cancelled!).
229     *
230     * @param dependency The command upon which 'other' depends
231     * @param other      The command to schedule when 'dependency' has finished
232     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
233     */
234    public CommandScheduler scheduleAfterOther(Command dependency, Command other) {
235        return schedule(other, dependency::justFinishedNoCancel);
236    }
237
238    /**
239     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
240     * just started.
241     *
242     * @param dependency The command upon which 'other' depends
243     * @param other      The command to schedule when 'dependency' has started
244     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
245     */
246    public CommandScheduler scheduleWithOther(Command dependency, Command other) {
247        return schedule(other, dependency::justStarted);
248    }
249
250    /**
251     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
252     * finished (but *not* been cancelled!) *and* 'additionalCondition' is true.
253     *
254     * @param dependency          The command upon which 'other' depends
255     * @param other               The command to schedule when 'dependency' has finished
256     * @param additionalCondition The additional condition necessary to be true to schedule the 'other' command
257     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
258     */
259    public CommandScheduler scheduleAfterOther(
260        Command dependency,
261        Command other,
262        BooleanSupplier additionalCondition
263    ) {
264        return schedule(
265            other,
266            () -> dependency.justFinishedNoCancel() && additionalCondition.getAsBoolean()
267        );
268    }
269
270    /**
271     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
272     * just started *and* 'additionalCondition' is also true.
273     *
274     * @param dependency          The command upon which 'other' depends
275     * @param other               The command to schedule when 'dependency' has started
276     * @param additionalCondition The additional condition necessary to be true to schedule the 'other' command
277     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
278     */
279    public CommandScheduler scheduleWithOther(
280        Command dependency,
281        Command other,
282        BooleanSupplier additionalCondition
283    ) {
284        return schedule(
285            other,
286            () -> dependency.justStarted() && additionalCondition.getAsBoolean()
287        );
288    }
289
290    /**
291     * Schedule the default command for a given subsystem. The default command will be run
292     * if no other command is currently running on that subsystem.
293     *
294     * @param command   The command to be run when others aren't using that subsystem
295     * @param subsystem The subsystem to run the command against when it's unused
296     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
297     */
298    public CommandScheduler scheduleDefault(Command command, Subsystem subsystem) {
299        if (command.getRequirements().contains(subsystem)) {
300            defaultMap.put(subsystem, command);
301            schedule(command, () -> getCurrent(subsystem) == command);
302        } else {
303            System.err.println(
304                "default commands must require their subsystem: " + command.getClass().toString()
305            );
306        }
307        return this;
308    }
309
310    /**
311     * Register a periodic function to be run once each schedule loop
312     *
313     * @param p The Periodic function to run
314     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
315     */
316    public CommandScheduler register(Periodic p) {
317        registered.add(p);
318        return this;
319    }
320
321    /**
322     * Get the default command that is running on the subsystem provided
323     *
324     * @param s The subsystem in question
325     * @return the default command for the subsystem, or null if there is none
326     */
327    @Nullable
328    public Command getDefault(Subsystem s) {
329        return opMode.getOpModeState() == CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN ? defaultMap.get(s) : null;
330    }
331
332    /**
333     * This gets the command currently using the subsystem provided
334     *
335     * @param s The subsystem in question.
336     * @return The Command currently using the subsystem, the default
337     * command for the subsystem, or null if there is no current
338     * command usint the subsystem, nor a default command
339     */
340    @Nullable
341    public Command getCurrent(Subsystem s) {
342        if (requirementMap.get(s) == null) return null;
343        for (Command c : requirementMap.get(s)) {
344            if (c.isRunning()) return c;
345        }
346        return getDefault(s);
347    }
348
349    /**
350     * Register a command to be scheduled. The 'supplier' function is what triggers
351     * the schedule to begin running the command.
352     *
353     * @param command  The command to schedule
354     * @param supplier The function that returns true when the command should be run
355     * @return the CommandScheduler singleton for easy chaining
356     */
357    public CommandScheduler schedule(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
358        commandMap.put(command, supplier);
359        for (Subsystem s : command.getRequirements()) {
360            requirementMap.putIfAbsent(s, new LinkedHashSet<>());
361            requirementMap.get(s).add(command);
362            register(s);
363        }
364        return this;
365    }
366
367    /**
368     * This is invoked from inside the CommandOpMode method, during the opCode.
369     * It it the core logic of actually scheduling &amp; running the commands.
370     */
371    public void run() {
372        // For each newly scheduled command,
373        // cancel any existing command that is using the new command's subsystem requirements
374        commandMap.forEach((c1, b) -> {
375            if (c1.justStarted()) {
376                for (Subsystem s : c1.getRequirements()) {
377                    for (Command c2 : requirementMap.get(s)) {
378                        if (c1 != c2) {
379                            c2.cancel();
380                        }
381                    }
382                }
383            }
384        });
385        commandMap.forEach((c1, b) -> {
386            if (b.getAsBoolean() || c1.isRunning()) {
387                c1.run();
388            }
389        });
390        registered.forEach(Periodic::periodic);
391    }
392}
